publisher.publisher-name: The New Testament Society of South Africa / Die Nuwe-Testamentiese Werkgemeenskap van Suid-Afrika

title-group.article-title: A STORY OF CONTEXTUAL HERMENEUTICS AND THE INTEGRITY OF NEW TESTAMENT INTERPRETATION IN SOUTH AFRICA

permissions.copyright-statement: COPYRIGHT © 1994 THE NEW TESTAMENT SOCIETY OF SOUTH AFRICA (NTSSA)

abstract.p: In a first part, the article tells the story of the Hermeneutics Group of the NTSSA. It is a story with three phases. In the first phase, interpretation was seen as more than the application of methods. In the second phase, the active role of the reader became more important. In the third phase, the importance of interpretive communities became more apparent. In a second part, some of the issues resulting from these developments are discussed under the rubric 'Why do we interpret the New Testament?' In a third part, the question is raised whether the Hermeneutics Group (and the NTSSA?) may be entering a new phase in its scholarly activity of dialogue with other reader-communities.
